policyViolationVulnerabilities.description: It was discovered that jQuery could allow for cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities to be introduced if `jQuery.htmlPrefilter` method is used. Attackers could exploit XSS vulnerabilities to execute JavaScript code in a target's browser by tricking them into accessing the vulnerable page. This would allow an attacker to steal an administrator's session tokens or execute arbitrary code on their behalf by sending the link to an unsuspecting user or waiting for them to discover it.
policyViolationVulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-0686
policyViolationVulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**3.5.0**](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/releases/tag/3.5.0) by [this](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/1d61fd94) commit and in [**4.0.0-beta**](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/releases/tag/4.0.0-beta) by [this](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/90fed4b4) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://jquery.com/download/).
policyViolationVulnerabilities.workaround: If the old behavior of `jQuery.htmlPrefilter` in jQuery **3.5.0** is required nonetheless, the vendor advises using `jQuery.UNSAFE_restoreLegacyHtmlPrefilter` from `jQuery Migrate` **3.2.0**. Since this reverses the security fix, it is also recommended to use `DOMPurify` plugin's `sanitize` method with `SAFE_FOR_JQUERY` set to `True` to properly sanitize user's HTML input again.

policyViolationVulnerabilities.description:
jQuery contains commented references to the hijacked domain `blindsignals`, within the source/non-minified versions of the files `src/queue/delay.js` and `test/data/jquery-1.9.1.js` (the former referring to a Web Archive version of the original site). References to this domain are not present in the minified files.

Users viewing the jQuery source code may attempt to follow links to the hijacked site without awareness of the domain's current status. This could expose them to attacks such as phishing, where they are tricked into supplying credentials or downloading malicious software. Users are not at risk if they do not manually follow links to the `blindsignals` domain.
policyViolationVulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2021-3651
policyViolationVulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in **[3.6.1](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/releases/tag/3.6.1)** by [this](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/4b0d8900) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://jquery.com/download/).
policyViolationVulnerabilities.workaround: Users should remove references to the `blindsignals` domain within `src/queue/delay.js` and `test/data/jquery-1.9.1.js`, to ensure anyone viewing these files does not try to follow links to the malicious domain.

policyViolationVulnerabilities.description:
It was discovered that jQuery could allow for cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities to be introduced if certain HTML is passed to Document Object Model (DOM) manipulation methods. Attackers could exploit XSS vulnerabilities to execute JavaScript code in a target browser by tricking them into accessing the vulnerable page. This would allow an attacker to steal an administrator's session tokens or execute arbitrary code on their behalf by sending the link to an unsuspecting user or waiting for them to discover it.

This vulnerability is listed as exploitable by the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency in their [Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog).
policyViolationVulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-0964
policyViolationVulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**3.5.0**](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/releases/tag/3.5.0) by [this](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/966a7090) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://jquery.com/download/).
policyViolationVulnerabilities.workaround: To work around this issue the vendor suggests using `DOMPurify` plugin with its `SAFE_FOR_JQUERY` option to sanitize the HTML string before passing it to a jQuery method.

policyViolationVulnerabilities.description: An improper input validation vulnerability has been discovered in jQuery. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability in order to add or modify properties that will exist on all objects. This could result in denial-of-service (DoS) conditions, or allow the attacker to tamper with application behavior through data injection.
policyViolationVulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2019-1138
policyViolationVulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**3.4.0**](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/releases/tag/3.4.0) by [this](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/753d591aea698e57d6db58c9f722cd0808619b1b) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://jquery.com/download/).
policyViolationVulnerabilities.workaround: Third party patches for previous jQuery versions can be found [here](https://github.com/DanielRuf/snyk-js-jquery-174006?files=1). Please be aware that these patches may not be fully tested.

policyViolationVulnerabilities.description: jQuery is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) due to the way it processes certain types of Ajax requests. This can allow potential attackers to execute arbitrary code on the target system.
policyViolationVulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2017-2930
policyViolationVulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**3.0.0-beta1**](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/releases/tag/3.0.0-beta1) by [this](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/b078a62013782c7424a4a61a240c23c4c0b42614) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://jquery.com/download/).
policyViolationVulnerabilities.workaround: The patch for this issue was erroneously backported to **1.12** / **2.2**, causing unintended problems. This change was reverted in **1.12.3** / **2.2.3**. The vendor has advised [here](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2432#issuecomment-403761229) that users should either upgrade to jQuery 3, or apply the patch manually.

policyViolationVulnerabilities.description: jQuery is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) due to lack of validation of user-supplied input. This could allow an attacker to inject arbitrary web scripts and steal a victim's session cookies.
policyViolationVulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2014-0063
policyViolationVulnerabilities.solution:
This vulnerability has been mitigated in **[3.0.0-rc1](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/releases/tag/3.0.0-rc1)** by [this](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/cfe468f29c4cbe1a457d0feb17dec90dcfd7c280) commit and [this](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/10fc59007d717432ea126e49ce4142e6c4d5136e) commit.

**Note**: This mitigation does not sanitize malicious input and will still allow scripts to be executed. The default behavior of the parser is changed such that if the context is unspecified, or given as `null`/`undefined`, a new `document` is created using `createHTMLDocument()`. This delays execution of parsed HTML until it is injected into the document, allowing the opportunity for tools to traverse the created DOM and remove unsafe content after the function call.

The latest stable releases are available [here](http://jquery.com/download/).
